aliases.name: Tik-Tik
aliases.meaning: Named for the sound it makes while flying

description.summary: A Filipino vampire-like creature that detaches its upper torso from its lower body at night, grows bat-like wings, and preys on pregnant women and sick people using its long proboscis tongue.
description.full: The Manananggal is a terrifying creature from Filipino folklore, particularly prominent in the Visayas region. By day, it appears as a beautiful woman living a normal life. By night, it undergoes a horrific transformation: its upper torso separates from its lower body at the waist, growing bat-like wings that allow it to fly in search of prey. The creature is especially feared for its predation on pregnant women, using its long, proboscis-like tongue to feed on unborn fetuses through roof thatch. The creature's name comes from 'tanggal' (to remove or separate), referring to its ability to detach its body. Its distinctive 'tik-tik' sound is said to work in reverse - louder when far away, softer when near, making it difficult for victims to judge their danger. The Manananggal can be killed by destroying its lower body while it is separated, typically by applying salt, garlic, or ash to prevent reconnection before sunrise.

etymology.origin: From Tagalog/Visayan 'tanggal' meaning 'to remove' or 'to separate'
etymology.first_use: Traditional folklore, pre-colonial origins with Spanish colonial influences

related_phenomena.name: Penanggalan
related_phenomena.description: Malaysian vampire that detaches only its head with trailing organs

related_phenomena.name: Aswang
related_phenomena.description: General category of Filipino shapeshifting creatures, Manananggal is a type of aswang

appearance_night.description: Upper torso separated, bat-like wings, fangs exposed, long proboscis tongue

features.description: Upper torso detaches from lower body at waist, lower body left standing or hidden
Large membranous wings emerge from severed torso for flight
Long, tubular tongue used to feed on victims
Sharp teeth visible in creature form
Eyes glow red in the dark

physical.morphology: By day: normal human woman. By night: separated upper torso with wings, lower body remains stationary

abilities.description: Can detach upper torso from lower body at waist
Flies using bat-like wings on separated upper torso
Appears as normal woman during day, transforms at night
Produces distinctive sound while flying - loud when far, soft when near (sound reversal)
Can feed through thatched roofs without entering

behavior.diet: Feeds on unborn fetuses (preferred), sick people, blood
patterns: Must reunite before sunrise or die
Uses tongue to feed through roofs

range.description: Primarily Philippines, especially the Visayas region. Also reported in other Filipino regions including Luzon and Mindanao.

first_recorded.source: Traditional Filipino folklore, predates Spanish colonization

peak_activity_periods.description: Strong presence in pre-colonial and colonial Filipino culture
Continues as active part of Filipino folk tradition and popular culture

origins.cultural_roots: Pre-colonial Filipino mythology, particularly from the Visayan peoples. The belief may have roots in indigenous animistic traditions combined with later influences.
origins.earliest_accounts: Oral traditions dating back to pre-colonial times. Documented by Spanish colonizers.
origins.folklore_connections: Related to broader Southeast Asian vampire mythology including Penanggalan (Malaysia), Krasue (Thailand), and part of the larger aswang tradition.

timeline.significance: Manananggal stories part of indigenous Filipino belief systems
Folklore documented by Spanish colonizers, merged with Catholic concepts
Folklore collected and preserved by Filipino scholars
Featured in Filipino films, TV shows, and literature

history.modern_era: The Manananggal remains a vital part of Filipino folklore and popular culture, appearing in movies, television, literature, and continuing as an active folk belief in rural areas.

traditions: Told as warning to pregnant women
stories: Stories of successful defense against manananggal
Tales of discovery and destruction of lower body
folklore.beliefs: Taken seriously in many rural Filipino communities. Pregnant women may take protective measures.

indigenous.significance: Important cautionary tale, reflects cultural anxieties about pregnancy, childbirth, and vulnerability of women and children.
indigenous.sensitivity_note: This is a living folk tradition. Researchers should approach Filipino perspectives with cultural respect and awareness.
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Recognize this as part of active Filipino cultural heritage, not mere superstition. Avoid dismissive or mocking treatment.

literature: "Philippine Folklore Stories" by John Maurice Miller
"Creatures of Philippine Lower Mythology" by Maximo Ramos
games: Referenced in international games with Filipino content
other: Subject of Filipino art and comics

preventive.description: Crucifix, holy water, blessed items for protection

offensive.description: Locate the separated lower body and destroy it, preventing reconnection
Apply to severed lower body to prevent reconnection, creature dies at sunrise
If upper body cannot reconnect before sunrise, it dies

sources.title: The Aswang Syncrasy in Philippine Folklore
